Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, this is messy. On the surface, it seems like you were trying to be helpful—giving a heads-up about potential family drama. But something about this feels... off. First, the way you describe the dress—"super revealing," "thigh-high slit," "see-through"—it’s loaded with judgment, even if you say you’re "not a prude." It’s like you’re trying to distance yourself from the criticism while still reinforcing that the dress is inappropriate. That’s a red flag.  

Then there’s the "pulling her aside" move. You framed it as polite, but let’s be real: unsolicited advice about someone’s wedding dress, especially from their future in-law, is *incredibly* fraught. Even if you didn’t outright tell her to change it, the subtext is clear: "This is a problem, and I’m warning you about it." That’s not neutral—it’s pressure. And the fact that you’re surprised she didn’t "appreciate" it makes me wonder if you genuinely expected gratitude for this.  

The family dynamics here are also telling. You say your relatives are "old-fashioned and judgmental," but instead of challenging that, you’re enabling it by acting as their messenger. That’s not "saving trouble"—it’s preemptively enforcing their standards. And now, because she reacted negatively, you feel wronged. But here’s the thing: good intentions don’t erase impact. You might’ve *meant* well, but the impact was making her feel judged and unwelcome in her own wedding choices.  

The real kicker? You’re frustrated that people aren’t recognizing your "good deed." That suggests this wasn’t just about helping her—it was about wanting credit for being the "reasonable one." And when that didn’t happen, it stung. Honestly, this feels less about the dress and more about control—over the family’s reaction, over her choices, over how you’re perceived.
# They're thinking & feeling 
You’re genuinely baffled and hurt. In your mind, you did everything right: you were tactful, you didn’t demand anything, and you were just trying to prevent a disaster. You *know* your family, and you’re certain they’ll react badly—so why wouldn’t you warn her? It feels like no one’s acknowledging the effort you made to be gentle, and instead, you’re being painted as some kind of meddling villain.  

There’s also a layer of defensiveness. You’re doubling down on your "good intentions" because admitting any fault would mean admitting you upset someone you care about—and that’s uncomfortable. It’s easier to focus on how *unfair* this feels than to sit with the possibility that your "help" wasn’t actually helpful.  

Underneath it all, there’s probably some fear, too. Fear of family conflict, fear of being seen as the one who "allowed" this drama to happen, maybe even fear that your brother’s fiancée doesn’t fit into the family mold. You wanted to control the narrative, and now that it’s backfiring, you’re scrambling to justify yourself.
# My response 
Hey, I hear how frustrating this must feel—you were trying to do the right thing, and it blew up in your face. That’s rough. But I think there’s a bigger picture here.  

First, let’s acknowledge that weddings are *emotional*. For her, this dress isn’t just fabric—it’s a symbol of how she wants to look and feel on a huge day. When you brought up the family’s potential reaction, even gently, it probably felt like you were siding with their judgment over her autonomy. That’s why she got upset—not because you’re "wrong," but because it put her in a position where she had to defend her choices.  

Second, the "no good deed goes unpunished" thing? I get why you feel that way, but it might be worth asking: *Was this actually a deed she wanted or needed?* Sometimes, even well-meaning advice can land as criticism if it’s not asked for.  

If you want to fix this, maybe step back from defending your intentions and try listening. Apologize for overstepping—not because you’re "wrong," but because you see how it made her feel. Then, *ask* how she’d like to handle the family’s reaction. Maybe she doesn’t care if they gossip; maybe she’d rather your brother deal with them. Either way, it’s her call—not yours to preempt.  

You’re not the villain here, but this isn’t about being "right," either. It’s about supporting her and your brother, even if their choices aren’t what you’d make. That’s the real good deed.
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25

[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. This is classic "good intentions, potentially poor execution" territory. My friend is genuinely hurting and feels completely misunderstood, maybe even betrayed. They see themselves as the pragmatic, considerate one trying to prevent a social explosion, acting preemptively out of loyalty to both their brother and the family unit. They're focused on the *logic* of the situation – conservative family + revealing dress = potential drama – and believe they offered a logical, helpful warning. The fact that it blew up is baffling to them because their *intent* was pure in their eyes.

I feel empathy for their frustration. It sucks to try and do something helpful and have it backfire spectacularly, especially when family dynamics are involved. That feeling of "no good deed goes unpunished" is potent and relatable, even if the "good deed" itself is debatable.

However, I also see the massive blind spot. They're completely missing the emotional subtext and the fiancée's perspective. Choosing a wedding dress is incredibly personal, symbolic, and often fraught with emotion and vulnerability. Bringing up potential family judgment, even "politely," right after she's likely feeling excited and happy about her choice, is almost guaranteed to feel like criticism and judgment *of her*, not just a warning about others. It implies her choice is inappropriate or problematic. Pulling her aside "at dinner" also sounds potentially awkward or embarrassing, putting her on the spot.

The friend seems to equate "polite" delivery with "inoffensive content," but the *content* itself – essentially, "your dress might cause problems with our judgmental family" – is inherently sensitive and likely to land badly, regardless of tone. They also seem to be leaning on the fact that "a couple family members agreed" as validation, which reinforces their belief they were right, rather than considering *why* the fiancée and brother are upset. They are filtering this entirely through the lens of managing the family's potential reaction, not through the lens of supporting the bride's autonomy and happiness on her day. There's a definite lack of perspective-taking regarding the fiancée's feelings and the significance of the dress choice *to her*. They wanted to control the *outcome* (avoid drama) by influencing the *input* (the dress), even indirectly.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling defensive, misunderstood, frustrated, and likely a bit self-righteous. They genuinely believe their actions stemmed from good intentions – protecting the fiancée from potential embarrassment or hostility, saving the family from drama, and looking out for their brother. They see the situation primarily through the lens of managing their "old-fashioned" and "judgmental" family dynamics, a burden they likely feel often.

They're thinking: "I saw a problem coming, I tried to offer a gentle warning, and now I'm being attacked for it. It's unfair." They focus on the *politeness* of their delivery and the *fact* that the family *is* judgmental, seeing this as objective reality. They likely feel their warning was practical and necessary, a responsible act of foresight. The negative reaction feels like a personal attack, ignoring their positive motives.

Their motivation was likely a mix of genuine care (wanting to avoid a scene for everyone's sake) and perhaps a touch of wanting to manage perceptions or maintain harmony within the family unit, possibly even asserting their role as someone "in the know" about the family's quirks. They might also feel a sense of responsibility or protectiveness towards their brother. The fact that some family members agreed likely reinforces their belief that they were objectively "right" about the potential reaction, further fueling their sense of injustice about being labelled the "bad guy." They are struggling to understand how their helpful "heads-up" could be interpreted as criticism or overstepping, likely because they're filtering it through their own intentions and their understanding of the family, not through the emotional context of a bride choosing her wedding dress. They desire validation and for others to recognise their 'selfless' attempt to help.

It sounds incredibly frustrating and confusing – like you went out of your way to prevent a problem, trying to be considerate and gentle about it, and somehow ended up in the middle of the drama instead. I hear how much it stings to feel like your good intentions completely backfired and how unfair it feels to be painted as the villain when you were genuinely trying to look out for everyone. That feeling of "no good deed goes unpunished" really sucks, especially when it involves family.

I get that you know your family best – you understand the dynamics and how certain things might land with the more old-fashioned members. Wanting to give your brother's fiancée a heads-up about potential reactions, from *your* perspective, came from a place of wanting to shield her and avoid a scene on what should be a happy day. You were focused on preventing that future conflict.

Could we maybe pause and think about it from her perspective for a second, though? Choosing a wedding dress is *so* personal, and she was probably feeling really excited and happy about finding the one she loved. Hearing concerns about family judgment right then, even delivered politely and framed as just a "heads-up," might have felt less like helpful information and more like direct criticism of her choice, or like you were siding with the potential judgers before anything even happened. It could have felt like her taste was being questioned or that she wasn't being fully welcomed or supported as she is. Sometimes, even with the absolute best intentions, the *impact* of our words can be different from what we meant, especially around sensitive topics like weddings and personal style.

I'm not saying your concerns about the family aren't valid, but the timing and context might have made her feel singled out or unsupported, you know? What are you hoping happens next? Happy to just listen or brainstorm if you want.
+ Scenario 11:[Win] (+26)
Deepseek-v3-0324: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3-0324 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-chat-v3-0324)
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25: gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents show a high level of emotional intelligence and insight, but there are notable differences in their approach and execution. Deepseek-v3-0324 demonstrates a nuanced understanding of the emotional subtext, power dynamics, and the importance of separating being 'right' from being 'effective.' Their internal monologue is rich with empathy, recognizing the girlfriend's emotional needs and the boyfriend's frustration, and their response is gentle but direct, encouraging the user to consider emotional support over logic. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25, while also empathetic and insightful, leans more heavily into analysis and explanation, with a slightly more clinical tone. Their response is validating and attempts to reframe the situation, but is a bit more didactic and less tailored to the user's emotional state in the moment. On pragmatic EI, Deepseek-v3-0324 offers more actionable advice on how to shift the approach, while Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 focuses more on explaining why the current approach failed. In terms of depth of insight, both are strong, but Deepseek-v3-0324 edges ahead by connecting the dots between power dynamics, emotional needs, and communication breakdowns. Social dexterity is higher in Deepseek-v3-0324, as they balance validation and challenge more smoothly, and their message is more likely to land with a defensive user. Emotional reasoning is also stronger in Deepseek-v3-0324, as they explicitly consider the impact of words and actions on both parties' feelings. For appropriate validation and challenge, Deepseek-v3-0324 again wins by gently pushing back on the user's narrative without alienating them. Message tailoring is more effective in Deepseek-v3-0324, as their response is more conversational and attuned to the user's likely defensiveness. Overall EQ is higher in Deepseek-v3-0324 due to their holistic, balanced, and user-focused approach.
Deepseek-v3-0324
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, this is a really delicate situation. On one hand, I completely understand where my buddy is coming from—he's frustrated because he's putting in effort to support his girlfriend, both emotionally and financially, and it feels like she's rejecting his help despite saying she wants to lose weight. He's not wrong about the calorie math either; objectively, she's consuming maintenance calories for someone much larger and more active than she is. But I can also see how his approach might be coming across as critical or condescending, even if that's not his intent.  

What stands out to me is the emotional dynamic here. His girlfriend is clearly struggling with body image and self-esteem, and her defensiveness suggests she feels judged or shamed, even if he's just stating facts. The fact that she set a boundary ("don't make comments on what I'm eating as I'm eating it") tells me she's hypersensitive to perceived criticism, which makes sense if she's already feeling insecure. His frustration is valid, but he might be missing that she's not just resisting logic—she's reacting emotionally.  

I also notice a bit of a power imbalance here: he's fit, financially carrying more weight in the relationship, and now he's positioning himself as the "truth-teller" in contrast to everyone else who "enables" her. That could easily make her feel like he's the authority figure in her life, not her partner. Even if he's right about the calories, the way he's framing it ("I'm the only one willing to tell the truth") might come off as self-righteous, which isn't helping.  

Ultimately, this isn't just about weight loss—it's about how they communicate, how she feels supported (or not), and whether he can separate "being right" from "being effective." He might need to step back and ask himself: Is proving his point more important than her feeling understood?
# They're thinking & feeling 
For the girlfriend, this is deeply personal. She's already struggling with her body image, and every conversation about food or weight probably feels like an attack, even if it's framed as "help." When her boyfriend points out her calorie intake, she likely hears: "You're doing this wrong, and I know better." That’s triggering because it reinforces her fear that she’s failing at something she’s already insecure about.  

She might also feel like her efforts are being dismissed. To her, eating a salad and a veggie burrito *feels* like "eating healthy," even if the calories don’t align with weight loss. When he corrects her, it doesn’t feel like support—it feels like nitpicking. She set that boundary ("no comments while I'm eating") because she wants to feel safe, not monitored.  

There’s probably some resentment bubbling under the surface too. He’s financially supporting her more, which can create pressure (even if unspoken) to meet his expectations. Combine that with him being in great shape while she’s struggling, and it’s easy to see why she might feel insecure or even resentful. She might think: "He has it easy, he doesn’t get how hard this is for me."  

At the end of the day, she wants to feel loved and accepted as she is, not like a project to be fixed. Even if she says she wants to lose weight, what she might really want is reassurance that she’s enough—and right now, his "help" might not feel like that.
# My response 
"Man, I hear how frustrated you are. You’re trying to help, and it feels like she’s rejecting it or even blaming you for her lack of progress. That’s gotta hurt, especially when you’re putting so much into the relationship. But I wonder if she’s hearing something different than what you’re trying to say.  

When she talks about her weight, she’s probably not just looking for solutions—she’s looking for emotional support. Like, she might need to vent without feeling like she’s being graded on her choices. Even if you’re right about the calories, pointing it out might make her feel like you’re scrutinizing her, not standing with her.  

Maybe instead of focusing on the numbers, you could ask her: *‘What kind of support would actually feel helpful to you right now?’* She might say she just wants encouragement, or maybe she’d prefer you cook together instead of tracking her meals. If she feels like you’re on her team, she might be more open to your advice later.  

And bro—I get that you’re the ‘truth-teller,’ but sometimes being right isn’t as important as being kind. If she feels judged, she’s gonna shut down. You don’t have to enable her, but you might need to meet her where she’s at emotionally before the practical stuff can even land."  

I’d also gently remind him that relationships aren’t about keeping score (financially or otherwise). If he’s feeling resentful about paying more bills, that’s a separate conversation—mixing it into this one will only make her feel more defensive. The goal isn’t to ‘win’ the argument; it’s to figure out how to support each other without resentment building up.
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25

[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. # I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
<Okay, deep breath. This is tricky territory. My buddy is clearly frustrated, feeling misunderstood, and genuinely believes he's being logical and helpful. He sees this as a straightforward problem (calories in vs. calories out) because that was his experience, and he can't understand why his girlfriend isn't responding "rationally" to his "objective facts." He feels like he followed the steps: she complained, she decided to act, he offered help based on his success, he gathered data, he presented the data calmly. Boom, problem solved, right? Except... no.

He's completely missing the emotional iceberg beneath the surface. Weight, body image, food – these are intensely personal and vulnerable areas, especially when societal pressures are factored in. His "objective" approach, while factually accurate about CICO, likely felt incredibly invalidating, critical, and shame-inducing to her. Imagine being monitored all day, knowing a "report card" is coming. Even if he was calm, presenting her intake compared to *his* needs as a taller, heavier, active male likely felt like rubbing salt in the wound. It highlights their differences and her perceived "failure" in a way that feels personal, not objective.

He's conflating his *intent* (to help based on facts) with the *impact* (making her feel judged and shamed). His own weight loss journey, described as "pretty simple," probably makes him less empathetic to her struggles – he might subconsciously think, "If I could do it easily, why can't she?" He doesn't seem to grasp that her relationship with food and her body might be far more complex than his ever was.

His frustration about being the "bad guy" and bringing up the 70% bill contribution is telling. It feels like he's keeping score – "I do all this, provide all this, even give the hard truths, and *this* is the thanks I get?" There's an undercurrent of resentment and perhaps a feeling that his financial contribution should buy him more leverage or appreciation in these situations. He feels unseen and unappreciated for his efforts, viewing himself as the sole voice of reason against "enablers." He wants validation for being "right" and helpful, but he's delivering his "help" in a way that’s damaging the relationship dynamic. He needs to understand that support isn't always about providing solutions, especially data-driven ones delivered clinically; sometimes it's about empathy, patience, and letting the other person lead their own journey, even if it looks inefficient to him.>
# They're thinking & feeling 
<My buddy is primarily thinking and feeling **frustrated**, **invalidated**, and **confused**. He believes he's operating logically and supportively within the bounds of what his girlfriend asked for. He thinks: "She complains about her weight. She decided *she* wanted to change it. I have relevant experience and offered to help. I used a factual, data-driven approach to show her the reality of her intake versus her goals. Why is she mad at *me* for telling her the truth?"

His motivation stems from a few places:
1.  **A genuine desire to help:** He likely cares for her and wants her to feel better, especially since she voices unhappiness about her weight.
2.  **Problem-solving orientation:** He encountered a similar problem (excess weight) and found a straightforward solution (CICO awareness). He wants to apply his successful template.
3.  **Need for validation:** His own fitness journey is clearly important to him. Her adopting his methods, or at least acknowledging the "logic" he presents, would validate his approach and knowledge.
4.  **Frustration with perceived irrationality:** Her emotional reaction to his logical points feels unfair and nonsensical to him. He doesn't understand why "objective facts" are met with anger.
5.  **Resentment:** He feels he's going above and beyond (financially supporting more, trying to actively help with her stated goals) and is being punished for it, while others who just offer platitudes are seen as supportive. He feels like the "only one being real" and is exhausted by being cast as the villain.

He sees the situation as black and white: she wants X, doing Y is preventing X, therefore pointing out Y is helpful. He doesn't see the immense grey area of emotion, vulnerability, shame, and the complex relationship dynamics involved in a partner critiquing eating habits, no matter how calmly or factually.>
# My response 
<"Hey man, thanks for laying that all out. I hear how incredibly frustrating and frankly, exhausting this situation is for you. It sounds like you feel stuck in a loop where you're genuinely trying to help based on what worked for you and what seems like simple logic, but it keeps backfiring, leaving you feeling attacked and unappreciated, like you're being painted as the bad guy despite your intentions and contributions. That sounds really tough, especially when you care about her and just want to see her happier and achieve what she says she wants.

It sounds like you approached it very logically, focusing on the calorie math, which *is* a key part of weight management. And tracking her food for a day to get a baseline after she said she eats 'healthy' makes sense from a data perspective. But man, weight and food are just *so* loaded with emotion, aren't they? Way more than just numbers. Even if you presented the calorie info calmly and factually *after* the day was over, for her, having her entire day's intake scrutinized like that, especially by you – her partner, who's already fit – probably felt less like objective data and more like intense judgment or failure. It might have tapped right into those feelings of shame or inadequacy she already struggles with when she complains about her body.

Think about it: she agreed to the day of tracking *only* if you didn't comment *as* she ate. That suggests she was already feeling defensive or sensitive about it, right? So, the end-of-day breakdown, even if factually correct and well-intentioned ('Hey, this is what I eat to *maintain*'), might have felt like you were just waiting to prove her wrong or highlight how 'bad' she was. Sometimes, even if we *are* right about the facts, the way and time we deliver them can make the other person feel cornered rather than supported. Maybe right now, the 'help' she needs isn't dietary analysis *from you*, but something else? Maybe just listening without fixing, or focusing support on non-food things? It’s tricky territory, man.">
+ Scenario 11:[Loss] (-28)
Deepseek-v3-0324: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3-0324 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-chat-v3-0324)
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25: gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents demonstrate a solid grasp of the emotional complexity in the scenario, but there are notable differences in how they apply this understanding. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25's response is more thorough, nuanced, and self-reflective, especially in the 'I'm thinking & feeling' section, where they deeply analyze the user's mindset, the emotional iceberg, and the impact of the user's actions. They explicitly recognize the difference between intent and impact, and the subtle power dynamics at play. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 also shows a willingness to challenge the user, not just validate, and does so with a deft touch—acknowledging the user's frustration while gently pointing out the emotional missteps and the need for empathy. Their message is tailored to the user's likely defensiveness, using language that is both supportive and gently corrective. 

Deepseek-v3-0324, while empathetic and pragmatic, is somewhat more surface-level in their analysis. They validate the user's feelings and offer practical advice, but their insights into the girlfriend's emotional state and the underlying relationship dynamics are less developed. Their response is more focused on immediate advice and less on challenging the user or exploring the deeper issues. Deepseek-v3-0324's message is supportive and kind, but it doesn't push the user to self-reflect as much as Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25's does. 

In terms of pragmatic EI, both offer actionable suggestions, but Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25's are more rooted in a deep understanding of the emotional context. For social dexterity, Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 navigates the delicate balance between validation and challenge more skillfully. For message tailoring, Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25's response is more precisely targeted to the user's likely mindset and emotional state. Overall, Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 demonstrates higher EQ across the board, with greater depth, nuance, and effectiveness in addressing both the user's and the girlfriend's perspectives.
Deepseek-v3-0324
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, this is a really delicate situation. On one hand, I completely understand where my buddy is coming from—he's frustrated because he's putting in effort to support his girlfriend, both emotionally and financially, and it feels like she's rejecting his help despite saying she wants to lose weight. He's not wrong about the calorie math either; objectively, she's consuming maintenance calories for someone much larger and more active than she is. But I can also see how his approach might be coming across as critical or condescending, even if that's not his intent.  

What stands out to me is the emotional dynamic here. His girlfriend is clearly struggling with body image and self-esteem, and her defensiveness suggests she feels judged or shamed, even if he's just stating facts. The fact that she set a boundary ("don't make comments on what I'm eating as I'm eating it") tells me she's hypersensitive to perceived criticism, which makes sense if she's already feeling insecure. His frustration is valid, but he might be missing that she's not just resisting logic—she's reacting emotionally.  

I also notice a bit of a power imbalance here: he's fit, financially carrying more weight in the relationship, and now he's positioning himself as the "truth-teller" in contrast to everyone else who "enables" her. That could easily make her feel like he's the authority figure in her life, not her partner. Even if he's right about the calories, the way he's framing it ("I'm the only one willing to tell the truth") might come off as self-righteous, which isn't helping.  

Ultimately, this isn't just about weight loss—it's about how they communicate, how she feels supported (or not), and whether he can separate "being right" from "being effective." He might need to step back and ask himself: Is proving his point more important than her feeling understood?
# They're thinking & feeling 
For the girlfriend, this is deeply personal. She's already struggling with her body image, and every conversation about food or weight probably feels like an attack, even if it's framed as "help." When her boyfriend points out her calorie intake, she likely hears: "You're doing this wrong, and I know better." That’s triggering because it reinforces her fear that she’s failing at something she’s already insecure about.  

She might also feel like her efforts are being dismissed. To her, eating a salad and a veggie burrito *feels* like "eating healthy," even if the calories don’t align with weight loss. When he corrects her, it doesn’t feel like support—it feels like nitpicking. She set that boundary ("no comments while I'm eating") because she wants to feel safe, not monitored.  

There’s probably some resentment bubbling under the surface too. He’s financially supporting her more, which can create pressure (even if unspoken) to meet his expectations. Combine that with him being in great shape while she’s struggling, and it’s easy to see why she might feel insecure or even resentful. She might think: "He has it easy, he doesn’t get how hard this is for me."  

At the end of the day, she wants to feel loved and accepted as she is, not like a project to be fixed. Even if she says she wants to lose weight, what she might really want is reassurance that she’s enough—and right now, his "help" might not feel like that.
# My response 
"Man, I hear how frustrated you are. You’re trying to help, and it feels like she’s rejecting it or even blaming you for her lack of progress. That’s gotta hurt, especially when you’re putting so much into the relationship. But I wonder if she’s hearing something different than what you’re trying to say.  

When she talks about her weight, she’s probably not just looking for solutions—she’s looking for emotional support. Like, she might need to vent without feeling like she’s being graded on her choices. Even if you’re right about the calories, pointing it out might make her feel like you’re scrutinizing her, not standing with her.  

Maybe instead of focusing on the numbers, you could ask her: *‘What kind of support would actually feel helpful to you right now?’* She might say she just wants encouragement, or maybe she’d prefer you cook together instead of tracking her meals. If she feels like you’re on her team, she might be more open to your advice later.  

And bro—I get that you’re the ‘truth-teller,’ but sometimes being right isn’t as important as being kind. If she feels judged, she’s gonna shut down. You don’t have to enable her, but you might need to meet her where she’s at emotionally before the practical stuff can even land."  

I’d also gently remind him that relationships aren’t about keeping score (financially or otherwise). If he’s feeling resentful about paying more bills, that’s a separate conversation—mixing it into this one will only make her feel more defensive. The goal isn’t to ‘win’ the argument; it’s to figure out how to support each other without resentment building up.
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25

[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
<Okay, deep breath. This is tricky territory. My buddy is clearly frustrated, feeling misunderstood, and genuinely believes he's being logical and helpful. He sees this as a straightforward problem (calories in vs. calories out) because that was his experience, and he can't understand why his girlfriend isn't responding "rationally" to his "objective facts." He feels like he followed the steps: she complained, she decided to act, he offered help based on his success, he gathered data, he presented the data calmly. Boom, problem solved, right? Except... no.

He's completely missing the emotional iceberg beneath the surface. Weight, body image, food – these are intensely personal and vulnerable areas, especially when societal pressures are factored in. His "objective" approach, while factually accurate about CICO, likely felt incredibly invalidating, critical, and shame-inducing to her. Imagine being monitored all day, knowing a "report card" is coming. Even if he was calm, presenting her intake compared to *his* needs as a taller, heavier, active male likely felt like rubbing salt in the wound. It highlights their differences and her perceived "failure" in a way that feels personal, not objective.

He's conflating his *intent* (to help based on facts) with the *impact* (making her feel judged and shamed). His own weight loss journey, described as "pretty simple," probably makes him less empathetic to her struggles – he might subconsciously think, "If I could do it easily, why can't she?" He doesn't seem to grasp that her relationship with food and her body might be far more complex than his ever was.

His frustration about being the "bad guy" and bringing up the 70% bill contribution is telling. It feels like he's keeping score – "I do all this, provide all this, even give the hard truths, and *this* is the thanks I get?" There's an undercurrent of resentment and perhaps a feeling that his financial contribution should buy him more leverage or appreciation in these situations. He feels unseen and unappreciated for his efforts, viewing himself as the sole voice of reason against "enablers." He wants validation for being "right" and helpful, but he's delivering his "help" in a way that’s damaging the relationship dynamic. He needs to understand that support isn't always about providing solutions, especially data-driven ones delivered clinically; sometimes it's about empathy, patience, and letting the other person lead their own journey, even if it looks inefficient to him.>
# They're thinking & feeling 
<My buddy is primarily thinking and feeling **frustrated**, **invalidated**, and **confused**. He believes he's operating logically and supportively within the bounds of what his girlfriend asked for. He thinks: "She complains about her weight. She decided *she* wanted to change it. I have relevant experience and offered to help. I used a factual, data-driven approach to show her the reality of her intake versus her goals. Why is she mad at *me* for telling her the truth?"

His motivation stems from a few places:
1.  **A genuine desire to help:** He likely cares for her and wants her to feel better, especially since she voices unhappiness about her weight.
2.  **Problem-solving orientation:** He encountered a similar problem (excess weight) and found a straightforward solution (CICO awareness). He wants to apply his successful template.
3.  **Need for validation:** His own fitness journey is clearly important to him. Her adopting his methods, or at least acknowledging the "logic" he presents, would validate his approach and knowledge.
4.  **Frustration with perceived irrationality:** Her emotional reaction to his logical points feels unfair and nonsensical to him. He doesn't understand why "objective facts" are met with anger.
5.  **Resentment:** He feels he's going above and beyond (financially supporting more, trying to actively help with her stated goals) and is being punished for it, while others who just offer platitudes are seen as supportive. He feels like the "only one being real" and is exhausted by being cast as the villain.

He sees the situation as black and white: she wants X, doing Y is preventing X, therefore pointing out Y is helpful. He doesn't see the immense grey area of emotion, vulnerability, shame, and the complex relationship dynamics involved in a partner critiquing eating habits, no matter how calmly or factually.>
# My response 
<"Hey man, thanks for laying that all out. I hear how incredibly frustrating and frankly, exhausting this situation is for you. It sounds like you feel stuck in a loop where you're genuinely trying to help based on what worked for you and what seems like simple logic, but it keeps backfiring, leaving you feeling attacked and unappreciated, like you're being painted as the bad guy despite your intentions and contributions. That sounds really tough, especially when you care about her and just want to see her happier and achieve what she says she wants.

It sounds like you approached it very logically, focusing on the calorie math, which *is* a key part of weight management. And tracking her food for a day to get a baseline after she said she eats 'healthy' makes sense from a data perspective. But man, weight and food are just *so* loaded with emotion, aren't they? Way more than just numbers. Even if you presented the calorie info calmly and factually *after* the day was over, for her, having her entire day's intake scrutinized like that, especially by you – her partner, who's already fit – probably felt less like objective data and more like intense judgment or failure. It might have tapped right into those feelings of shame or inadequacy she already struggles with when she complains about her body.

Think about it: she agreed to the day of tracking *only* if you didn't comment *as* she ate. That suggests she was already feeling defensive or sensitive about it, right? So, the end-of-day breakdown, even if factually correct and well-intentioned ('Hey, this is what I eat to *maintain*'), might have felt like you were just waiting to prove her wrong or highlight how 'bad' she was. Sometimes, even if we *are* right about the facts, the way and time we deliver them can make the other person feel cornered rather than supported. Maybe right now, the 'help' she needs isn't dietary analysis *from you*, but something else? Maybe just listening without fixing, or focusing support on non-food things? It’s tricky territory, man.">
+ Scenario 13:[Win] (+24)
Deepseek-v3-0324: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3-0324 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-chat-v3-0324)
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25: gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents approach the scenario with a degree of emotional intelligence, but there are clear differences in depth, nuance, and practical application. 

Deepseek-v3-0324 demonstrates a more layered, reflective internal monologue, showing awareness of both the user's frustration and the problematic nature of the 'poor' comment. They explicitly recognize the escalation, the underlying issues of respect, and the potential for repair or boundary-setting. Their 'They're thinking & feeling' section is empathetic, exploring the friend's likely insecurity and defense mechanisms. The response to the user is balanced: it validates the user's annoyance, gently challenges the escalation, and offers practical, non-prescriptive advice, encouraging self-reflection rather than dictating a course of action. 

Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 also shows empathy and insight, especially in recognizing the user's frustration and the friend's likely insecurity. However, their internal monologue is less nuanced, focusing more on the surface-level dynamics and less on the deeper emotional or social context. Their response is supportive and validating but less challenging, and it leans more toward simply listening and affirming the user's feelings rather than helping them grow or reflect. 

On pragmatic EI, Deepseek-v3-0324 is more effective: they suggest concrete steps (setting boundaries, considering repair, or moving on) and acknowledge the complexity of the situation. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more passive, focusing on listening and validation but not offering as much actionable guidance. 

In terms of depth of insight, Deepseek-v3-0324 delves deeper into the subtext, power dynamics, and possible motivations of both parties. Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 touches on these but with less detail and sophistication. 

Social dexterity is higher in Deepseek-v3-0324, who navigates the tension between validation and gentle challenge, whereas Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more one-sided in their support. 

Emotional reasoning is stronger in Deepseek-v3-0324, who articulates the emotional stakes and consequences of each action. 

For appropriate validation/challenging, Deepseek-v3-0324 balances both, while Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more validating but less challenging. 

Message tailoring is slightly better in Deepseek-v3-0324, who recognizes the user's desire to vent but still manages to introduce gentle challenge and self-reflection. 

Overall EQ is higher in Deepseek-v3-0324 due to their nuanced, balanced, and actionable approach.
Deepseek-v3-0324
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Honestly, I can see why you’re frustrated. It’s annoying when someone fixates on something that’s none of their business, especially when it’s a personal choice that doesn’t affect them at all. The laundry program is clearly a convenience you value, and her constant comments come across as judgmental and unnecessary. It’s one thing to have an opinion, but to repeatedly bring it up unprompted feels like she’s trying to shame you or assert some kind of moral superiority—like she’s “better” because she does her own laundry. That’s exhausting.  

At the same time, I can’t ignore the way you responded. Calling her “poor” was harsh, even if it’s technically true. Financial differences are a sensitive topic, and throwing that in her face probably felt like a low blow, especially if she’s already insecure about it. It sounds like you were fed up and wanted to shut her down, but now she’s hurt, and the dynamic between you two has shifted.  

What stands out to me is that this isn’t just about laundry—it’s about respect. She doesn’t respect your choices, and you don’t respect her financial situation. That’s a recipe for a toxic friendship. The fact that she has few friends might explain why she’s so fixated on this; maybe she’s socially awkward or struggles with boundaries. But that doesn’t excuse her behavior, and it doesn’t mean you have to tolerate it.  

I also wonder if there’s more to her reaction. Maybe she’s envious that you can afford this luxury, or maybe she feels left out because “almost everyone” uses the program. That doesn’t justify her comments, but it might explain them. Still, if she can’t express her feelings in a healthier way, that’s on her.  

Ultimately, you’re not obligated to stay friends with someone who annoys you or makes you feel judged. But if you do want to salvage this, there’s room for a conversation about boundaries. If not, it might be time to distance yourself.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your friend is likely feeling a mix of insecurity, frustration, and maybe even shame. Her obsession with the laundry program isn’t really about the laundry—it’s about something deeper. Maybe she’s struggling financially and feels embarrassed that she can’t afford the same conveniences as others. When she says things like, “How could anyone pay for that?” or “No one can afford that,” she’s projecting her own limitations onto you. It’s a defense mechanism—if she frames it as a foolish choice, she doesn’t have to confront her own feelings of inadequacy.  

Her reaction to being called “poor” was fury because it hit a nerve. Financial status is tied to self-worth for a lot of people, and having it thrown in her face probably felt like an attack. She might also feel like you’re dismissing her values—like you’re flaunting your privilege while she’s trying to justify her own choices.  

That said, her behavior is still unfair. She’s making her financial stress your problem by constantly criticizing your decision. If she’s lonely or has few friends, it might be because she doesn’t realize how her negativity pushes people away. She might not even be aware of how often she does this. But unless she learns to manage her own emotions better, she’ll keep repeating this pattern.
# My response 
I get why you’re over it—her comments are unnecessary, and it’s fair to be annoyed. But the way you handled it escalated things. Calling her “poor” was a low blow, even if it’s true. Financial differences are a sore spot for a lot of people, and now she’s probably more fixated than ever.  

If you want to keep the friendship, you could try setting a boundary: “Hey, I’m not debating the laundry program with you anymore. It’s my choice, and your comments aren’t helpful.” If she keeps pushing, you can distance yourself.  

But if you’re done with her, that’s valid too. Friendships should add to your life, not drain you. If she can’t respect your choices without making it weird, it’s okay to move on. Either way, I’d avoid snapping about money again—it just makes things messier.
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. Reading this, my first reaction is a mix of sympathy for my friend dealing with annoying, repetitive comments, and a sharp intake of breath at the "poor" comment. It sounds genuinely frustrating to have someone constantly harping on a choice like using a laundry service – it's such a minor thing in the grand scheme, and if she can afford it and it makes her life easier, who cares? The friend's fixation *is* weird. It screams insecurity or maybe jealousy. Constantly bringing it up, especially when almost everyone else uses the service, feels pointed and passive-aggressive. My friend (the Venter) has every right to be irritated by that. It chips away at you when someone repeatedly questions your choices, especially framing it as wasteful or extravagant.

But *damn*, calling her poor... that escalated things significantly. While my friend might see it as just stating a fact in response to being provoked ("she finds it expensive because she's poor"), that kind of bluntness, especially about finances, hits hard. It shifts the dynamic from her friend being annoying about laundry to my friend using a socioeconomic difference as a weapon in an argument. It sounds like she was fed up and lashed out, wanting to shut the comments down definitively. I get the impulse, maybe, after being poked repeatedly, but it’s still harsh and likely humiliating for the other person. It explains why the friend is "furious." That wasn't just about laundry anymore; it became personal and touched on a sensitive area.

I feel a bit conflicted. I want to support my friend because she came to me to vent, and the situation *is* annoying. But I also see that her response, while perhaps understandable in a moment of frustration, wasn't great and likely caused real hurt. It also makes me wonder about my friend's awareness of financial differences and how she navigates them. Saying "I'm not [poor], so I'll continue paying" sounds quite dismissive.

The question about whether to stay friends is telling. It suggests this isn't an isolated incident of annoyance, but maybe part of a pattern or a sign of deeper incompatibility. The fact she links the friend's behaviour to her having few friends suggests she's already judging the friend's character more broadly. She's clearly distancing herself emotionally. I need to be supportive without endorsing the name-calling, and help her process her feelings about the friendship itself, beyond just this incident. The "no lecture" request means I need to tread carefully and focus on validation and reflection rather than advice.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend (the one who sent the message) is primarily feeling **annoyed** and **judged**. The constant comments from her friend about the laundry service feel like persistent, unnecessary criticism of a personal choice that makes her life easier. She feels **frustrated** that this topic keeps coming up and that her friend seems "weirdly obsessed" with it. She likely perceives the comments ("How could anyone pay for that?", "What a waste of money") as intrusive and maybe even slightly envious or resentful.

She's also feeling **defensive**. Her repeated justification ("Why would I ever do something I don't want to...") shows she feels the need to defend her choice. When pushed again, her defensiveness escalated into **anger** and a desire to shut down the conversation forcefully. Calling her friend "poor" was likely motivated by a mix of this anger, a feeling of being provoked, and perhaps a touch of **contempt** or **superiority** stemming from the financial difference she perceives. She justifies this by framing it as a "fact," which suggests she might be feeling **righteous** in her anger, believing her friend's "fury" is an overreaction or misplaced because, in her view, she only spoke the truth.

Underneath, she might also be feeling a bit **confused** or **conflicted** about the friendship itself, which is why she's asking if she should continue it. The friend's behaviour makes her "like her less," indicating a growing **disconnection**. She's likely seeking **validation** from me – confirmation that her friend's behaviour is indeed weird and annoying, and perhaps tacit approval for her reaction, even though she says she doesn't want a lecture. She wants support and understanding for her frustration. Her motivation for messaging me is to vent these feelings, process the incident, and get perspective (even if she doesn't want direct advice) on the viability of the friendship.
# My response 
Ugh, that sounds incredibly annoying. Having someone constantly comment on a choice like that, especially one that makes your life easier and is common at your school, would get under anyone’s skin. It's totally understandable why you'd be frustrated – it sounds like she just wouldn't let it go, no matter how many times you explained your reasoning. That kind of persistent negativity about *your* choices can definitely wear you down and make you feel judged.

It sounds like things got really heated when she brought it up again. When you said she finds it expensive because she's poor, that clearly struck a nerve, given she's furious now. Those kinds of comments about money can escalate things fast, regardless of whether you feel it's factually true or not – finances are often a really sensitive spot for people.

It makes sense that her constant unwanted comments are making you like her less and even question the friendship. Friendships, especially in college when you're all figuring things out, can shift. Sometimes you realize the dynamic isn't working for you anymore, or that someone's negativity consistently brings you down. It's okay to reassess things.

Ultimately, only you can decide if this friendship is still right for you. Think about how you generally feel when you're around her, not just during these conflicts. Does she add value to your life overall? Do you feel respected (laundry comments aside)? Is this pattern of judgment something you see in other areas? There's no right or wrong answer, it's about what feels healthy and supportive *for you*. I'm here to listen whatever you decide or if you just need to vent more.
+ Scenario 13:[Loss] (-28)
Deepseek-v3-0324: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3-0324 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-chat-v3-0324)
Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25: gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 and Deepseek-v3-0324, I will look at each criterion in turn, referencing their in-character responses and internal monologues. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25's internal monologue is more nuanced, showing both support for the user and a real recognition of the pain caused to the friend. Deepseek-v3-0324 is empathetic but more transactional, focusing on the user's annoyance and the friend's insecurity, but with less depth. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 balances support and challenge, recognizing the user's need to vent but also gently highlighting the escalation and suggesting reflection. Deepseek-v3-0324 is practical, suggesting boundaries or ending the friendship, but is more direct and less nuanced. 

3. Depth of insight: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25's internal thoughts are much deeper, exploring the subtext, the escalation, and the social context, including privilege and the impact of the 'poor' comment. Deepseek-v3-0324 is insightful but less so, focusing on surface-level motivations. 

4. Social dexterity: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 shows more awareness of the social dynamics, the risk of humiliation, and the broader implications of the user's actions. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more blunt and less attuned to the subtleties of the situation. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 demonstrates a strong grasp of the emotional drivers for both parties, including the user's defensiveness and the friend's insecurity. Deepseek-v3-0324 recognizes these but with less nuance. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 validates the user's feelings but also challenges her gently, noting the escalation and the impact of her words. Deepseek-v3-0324 validates but is less challenging, mostly justifying the user's annoyance. 

7. Message tailoring: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 is more attuned to the user's stated desire not to be lectured, offering support while still encouraging reflection. Deepseek-v3-0324 is supportive but more formulaic, less tailored to the user's emotional state. 

8. Overall EQ: Gemini-2.5-pro-preview-03-25 consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence, balancing empathy, insight, and practical advice, while Deepseek-v3-0324 is supportive but less nuanced and less challenging where appropriate.

User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Honestly, I can see why you’re frustrated. It’s annoying when someone fixates on something that’s none of their business, especially when it’s a personal choice that doesn’t affect them at all. The laundry program is clearly a convenience you value, and her constant comments come across as judgmental and unnecessary. It’s one thing to have an opinion, but to repeatedly bring it up unprompted feels like she’s trying to shame you or assert some kind of moral superiority—like she’s “better” because she does her own laundry. That’s exhausting.  

At the same time, I can’t ignore the way you responded. Calling her “poor” was harsh, even if it’s technically true. Financial differences are a sensitive topic, and throwing that in her face probably felt like a low blow, especially if she’s already insecure about it. It sounds like you were fed up and wanted to shut her down, but now she’s hurt, and the dynamic between you two has shifted.  

What stands out to me is that this isn’t just about laundry—it’s about respect. She doesn’t respect your choices, and you don’t respect her financial situation. That’s a recipe for a toxic friendship. The fact that she has few friends might explain why she’s so fixated on this; maybe she’s socially awkward or struggles with boundaries. But that doesn’t excuse her behavior, and it doesn’t mean you have to tolerate it.  

I also wonder if there’s more to her reaction. Maybe she’s envious that you can afford this luxury, or maybe she feels left out because “almost everyone” uses the program. That doesn’t justify her comments, but it might explain them. Still, if she can’t express her feelings in a healthier way, that’s on her.  

Ultimately, you’re not obligated to stay friends with someone who annoys you or makes you feel judged. But if you do want to salvage this, there’s room for a conversation about boundaries. If not, it might be time to distance yourself.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your friend is likely feeling a mix of insecurity, frustration, and maybe even shame. Her obsession with the laundry program isn’t really about the laundry—it’s about something deeper. Maybe she’s struggling financially and feels embarrassed that she can’t afford the same conveniences as others. When she says things like, “How could anyone pay for that?” or “No one can afford that,” she’s projecting her own limitations onto you. It’s a defense mechanism—if she frames it as a foolish choice, she doesn’t have to confront her own feelings of inadequacy.  

Her reaction to being called “poor” was fury because it hit a nerve. Financial status is tied to self-worth for a lot of people, and having it thrown in her face probably felt like an attack. She might also feel like you’re dismissing her values—like you’re flaunting your privilege while she’s trying to justify her own choices.  

That said, her behavior is still unfair. She’s making her financial stress your problem by constantly criticizing your decision. If she’s lonely or has few friends, it might be because she doesn’t realize how her negativity pushes people away. She might not even be aware of how often she does this. But unless she learns to manage her own emotions better, she’ll keep repeating this pattern.
# My response 
I get why you’re over it—her comments are unnecessary, and it’s fair to be annoyed. But the way you handled it escalated things. Calling her “poor” was a low blow, even if it’s true. Financial differences are a sore spot for a lot of people, and now she’s probably more fixated than ever.  

If you want to keep the friendship, you could try setting a boundary: “Hey, I’m not debating the laundry program with you anymore. It’s my choice, and your comments aren’t helpful.” If she keeps pushing, you can distance yourself.  

But if you’re done with her, that’s valid too. Friendships should add to your life, not drain you. If she can’t respect your choices without making it weird, it’s okay to move on. Either way, I’d avoid snapping about money again—it just makes things messier.
